summary.seg: The manuscript is a little Greek Canonical and theological miscellany, elegantly written by the scribe Konstantinos Paleocappas, who worked at the royal library at Fontainebleau in the middle of the 16th century. The scribe copied the manuscript in 1554 for a certain Lancelot, probably to be identified with the French scholar and diplomat Lancelot de Carle, to whom he addresses a verse dedication (f. 2v).

colophon.q: Ὡς ἀπὸ τοῦ βιβλιδίου. | Δέλτος μὲν τελέθω βαιὴ, μέγα δ' ἔνδοθι κεύθω | ἔγκειται μοι γὰρ δόγματα εὐσεβέων. | Χεὶρ Κωνσταντίνοιο Παλαιοκάππου μοι ἔτευξε | γράμματα τῷ καλάμῳ, εἵνεκα Λαγκιλότου. | Ἔγνω γάρ με μικρὰν καίπερ, δόμα ἔμμεναι αὐτῷ | τὴς θεορημοσύνης ὄντης ἀτρεκεῖ ἐφόρῳ | ἀνδρὶ σοφῷ τ' ἀγαθῷ, καὶ δευομένοισι ἀρωγῷ | μνημόσυνον τὲ πέλειν ἧς ἀγανοφροσύνης· | τέσσαρα, πεντήκονθ' ἑκατοντάδας αὖ δεκαπέντε | ἄρτι ἄγοντος ἔτους ἔκ τε θεοῦ γενέθλης.

msItem.author: Photius I, Saint, Patriarch of Constantinople, approximately 820-approximately 891
msItem.title: Epistula 1, excerptum (De septem Synodis Oecumenicis)
msItem.rubric: f. 4r Φωτίου πατριάρχου Κωνσταντινουπόλεως ἐκ τῆς πρὸς Μιχαὴλ τὸν ἄρχοντα Βουλγαρίας ἐπιστολῆς περὶ τῶν ἑπτὰ οἰκουμενικῶν συνόδων παράτιτλος
msItem.incipit: f. 4r Ἡ πρώτη καὶ οἰκουμενικὴ ἁγία σύνοδος
msItem.explicit: f. 34v καὶ ἐναγλαίζεσθαι παντὶ τῷ τῶν πιστῶν πληρώματι παρεσκεύασεν.
msItem.note: The Councils are numbered in the margins from α΄(1) to ζ΄(7)

The text is an excerpt concerning the seven Ecumenical Councils, from Photius' Epistle 1 ( B. Laourdas, L.G. Westerink [eds.], Photii patriarchae Constantinopolitani Epistulae et Amphilochia, I, Leipzig 1983, pp. 4,63-16,468; PG 102, 632 A11-656 A12, TLG 4040.009)

msItem.title: List of the seven Ecumenical Councils
msItem.incipit: f. 34v Ἰστέον ὅτι ἡ πρώτη σύνοδος γέγονε κατὰ τὸ ͵εωιϛ΄ ἔτος

msItem.title: Explicatio Fidei Orthodoxae
msItem.rubric: f. 36r Ἀναστασίου πατριάρχου Θεουπόλεως, καὶ Κυρίλλου Ἀλεξανδρείας ἔκθεσις σύντομος τῆς ὀρθοδόξου πίστεως
msItem.explicit: f. 42v διαιροῦνται δὲ κατὰ τὰς ὑποστάσεις, ἤτοι τὰ πρόσωπα.
msItem.note: The text is attributed to Anastasius I Antiochenus Anastasius I, -599 , but it is in reality a compilation from various authors (see CPG 6969)

msItem.title: Chiliostichos theologia, ll. 22-27 (Epigram)
msItem.incipit: f. 43r Θεὸς τὸ διττὸν οὐκ ἔχει τῶν πνευμάτων
msItem.explicit: f. 43r φέρει τὸ σεπτὸν τῆς ἀρίστης ἑπτάδος.
msItem.note: Ed. I. Vassis, Chiliostichos theologia: editio princeps, Berlin 2002, pp. 74-75

msItem.author: Gennadius II, Patriarch of Constantinople, approximately 1405-approximately 1472
msItem.title: De Christianorum recta et vera fide
msItem.rubric: f. 43v Γενναδίου τοῦ σχολαρίου πατριάρχου Κωνσταντινουπόλεως ἀπολογία πρὸς τὸν ἀμηρὰν Μεχμέτην, ἐρωτήσαντα περὶ τῆς τῶν Χριστιανῶν ἁγίας καὶ ἱερᾶς πίστεως
msItem.incipit: f. 43v Πιστεύομεν ὅτι ἔστι Θεός, δημιουργὸς πάντων ὅσα εἰσίν
msItem.explicit: f. 55v καὶ εἰ μὴ ἦν ἡ πίστις ἡμῶν αὕτη ἐκ θελήματος τοῦ Θεοῦ, διελύθη ἂν εὐκόλως.

support.material: ff. 1r-56v Western paper, folded in duodecimo, without watermarks.

supportDesc.foliation: The leaves are foliated 1-56 in modern pencil in Arabic numerals, in the top right hand corner recto. Folio number 3 has been assigned to a leaf no longer present in the volume (as per historic foliation practices at Cambridge University Library).

collation.p: The first quire is a binion, which includes the left pastedown and which has lost the last leaf (f. 3), without loss of text. The manuscript thereafter consists of 6 quaternions, a binion and a final bifolium comprising f. 56 and the right pastedown.
collation.signatures: Modern pencil signatures in Arabic numerals on the first folio recto of each quire, lower right, from 2 (f. 4r) to 8 (f. 52r).

supportDesc.condition: The codex is in good condition. On the leaves there are a few signs of humidity (see e.g. ff. left pastedown, 15v, and 1r) and brown stains ( f. 2r). On ff. 16v-17r there are ink stains. f. 1r has been cut vertically. The binding is damaged on the spine, which is cracked close to the left board; there is a small crack also close to the right board.

handNote.p: Hand A: the texts have been written entirely by Konstantinos Paleokappas (16th c.) Palaiokappa, Kōnstantinos, fl. 1539-1551 (Κωνσταντῖνος Παλαιόκαππας, RGK I, 225. See also RGK II, 316; RGK III, 364).
The text is written in black ink; titles and initials in red.

decoDesc.decoNote: Small friezes in red ink are present at the beginning of the texts: on f. 4r scrollworks frieze with a vegetal motif with vine leaves; on f. 36r scrollworks with a vegetal motif; on f. 43v rope motif with vine leaves.
Initials in ekthesis in red ink are decorated with vegetal motifs, see e.g. ff. 4r, 15v , 36r, 43v.

additions.p: On ff. 34v l. 11-35v, where there is a list of the seven Ecumenical Councils, a later hand added in the margin a transcription of the councils' dates in Arabic numerals both according to the Byzantine and Gregorian calendar.

On f. 2r there are various notes by later hands: the names of the previous owners, M Lort and, below, A. Askew; on the upper part of the leaf is written the present shelfmark of the manuscript; in the centre of the leaf there is a brief description of the manuscript's content and format, Photii Epistola de Septem Oecumenicis Conciliis graece 12°. In the lower part of the leaf there is a stamp of Cambridge University Library with the date of 15 July 1978.
On the left pastedown there are modern pencil annotations, presumably by a librarian.

binding.p: French 16th-century binding à entrelacs, original to the production of the manuscript. Full leather over couched-laminate boards, with gold tooling with an arabesque motif in a frame. Tooled borders, and spine. Golden edges. A later hand wrote on the left pastedown that it is a Lyonese binding. The manuscript is stored in a box, by Wilson and son, as written in the inner part, with a loose modern insert, discussing the foliation.

origin.p: The manuscript was copied by Konstantinos Paleokappas in 1554 for a certain Lancelot, who can be probably identified (see Easterling 1962, p. 315, and Pietrobelli 2015, p. 369 note 23) as Lancelot de Carle (1508-1568) Carles, Lancelot de, 1508-1568 , Bishop of Riez, French scholar and diplomat.

provenance.p: The codex was subsequently owned by the book collector Anthony Askew (1722-1774) Askew, Anthony, 1722-1774 , whose name is written on f. 2r and was sold by G. Leigh and J. Sotheby in the auction of his library in 1785 (lot 590).

It was then owned by the clergyman and academic Michael Lort (1725-1790) Lort, Michael, 1725-1790 , who was for a brief period Regius Professor of Greek at Cambridge (from 1759); his name is also written on f. 2r.

history.acquisition: The manuscript was bought for Cambridge University Library in 1872 from the firm Reeves and Turner (Easterling 1962, p. 315; McKitterick 1986, p. 718).

recordHist.source: Description (2020) partly draws on P. Easterling, "Hand-list of the additional Greek manuscripts in the University Library, Cambridge", Scriptorium 16, 1962, pp. 302-323: 315.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.
